page.title: 10Shenington, Trinity Church
page.content: The church was built in 1125AD to 1400AD, the latest addition being the tower in the 15th century. The main part of the church is Hornton stone, but it was too soft for the tower so they used Clipsham stone which was much harder, but even though it is hard it has withered away. In 1879 the Norman arch which separated the chancel from the nave was moved to the front of the organ, so in place of it a bigger arch was built. By the pulpit there are stairs which lead up to to stalls above the old arch, but when the arch was moved so were the stalls. In 1879, a new one built by Eber Clifton, who was first to be baptised in it. Outside on the south facing is a stone carving of a man under an arch with an ox by his side. The man is said to be a priest either blessing livestock or the crops.
